column1: Information : September 25
Information : The First Bush-Dukakis Presidential Debate
Jim Lehrer : Good evening.
Jim Lehrer : On behalf of the Commission on Presidential Debates I am pleased to welcome you to this first presidential debate of the 1988 campaign.
Jim Lehrer : I'm Jim Lehrer of the McNeil-Lehrer News Hour.
Jim Lehrer : My colleagues on the panel are John Mashek of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution; Ann Groer of The Orlando Sentinel; and Peter Jennings of ABC News.
Jim Lehrer : For the next 90 minutes we will be questioning the candidates for president of the United States following a format designed and agreed to by representatives of the two candidates.
Jim Lehrer : The candidates are Vice President George Bush
column2: the Republican nominee; Governor Michael Dukakis
column3: the Democratic nominee.

column1: Jim Lehrer : (Applause)
Jim Lehrer : Our questions this evening will be about equally divided between foreign and domestic policy matters.
Jim Lehrer : The first question by agreement between the two candidates goes to Vice President Bush.
Jim Lehrer : It is a domestic question.
Jim Lehrer : You have two minutes for an answer
column2: sir.

column1: Jim Lehrer : The polls say the number one domestic issue to a majority of voters is drugs.
Jim Lehrer : What is there about these times that drives or draws so many Americans to use drugs?
George Bush : I think we've seen a deterioration of values.
George Bush : I think for a while as a nation we condoned those things we should have condemned.
George Bush : For a while
column2: as I recall
column3: it even seems to me that there was talk of legalizing or decriminalizing marijuana and other drugs
column4: and I think that's all wrong.

column1: George Bush : So we've seen a deterioration in values
column2: and one of the things that I think we should do about it in terms of cause is to instill values into the young people in our schools.

column1: George Bush : We got away
column2: we got into this feeling that value- free education was the thing.

column1: George Bush : And I don't believe that at all I do believe there are fundamental rights and wrongs as far as use.
George Bush : And
column2: of course
column3: as far as the how we make it better
column4: yes
column5: we can do better on interdiction.

column1: George Bush : But we've got to do a lot better on education
column2: and we have to do
column3: be tougher on those who commit crimes.

column1: George Bush : We've got to get after the users more.
George Bush : We have to change this whole culture.
George Bush : "You know
column2: I saw a movie - ""Crocodile Dundee."""

column1: George Bush : And I saw the cocaine scene treated with humor
column2: as though this was a humorous little incident.

column1: George Bush : And it's bad.
George Bush : Everybody ought to be in this thing.
George Bush : Entertainment industry
column2: people involved in the schools
column3: education.

column1: George Bush : And it isn't a Republican or a Democrat or a liberal problem.
George Bush : But we have got to instill values in these young people.

George Bush : And I have put forward a many-point drug program that includes what I would do as president of the United States; in terms of doing better on interdiction; and in terms of better in the neighborhoods.
George Bush : But I think we're all in this together
column2: and my plea to the American people is values in the schools.

column1: Jim Lehrer : Governor
column2: you have one minute to respond.

column1: Michael Dukakis : I agree with Mr. Bush that values are important.
Michael Dukakis : But it's important that our leaders demonstrate those values from the top.
Michael Dukakis : That means those of us who are elected to positions of political leadership have to reflect those values ourselves.
Michael Dukakis : Here we are with a government that's been dealing with a drug-running Panamanian dictator.
Michael Dukakis : We've been dealing with him; he's been dealing drugs to our kids.
Michael Dukakis : Governors like me and others have been trying to deal with the consequences.
Michael Dukakis : I remember being in a high school in my own state as we were organizing something we call the Governor's Alliance Against Drugs
column2: and a young 16 year old girl coming up to me
column3: desperate
column4: addicted
column5: dependent

column1: Michael Dukakis : We're providing that young woman with help.
Michael Dukakis : But I want to be a president of the United States who makes sure that we never again do business with a drug-running Panamanian dictator
column2: that we never again funnel aid to the contras through convicted drug dealers.

column1: Michael Dukakis : Values begin at the top
column2: in the White House.

column1: Michael Dukakis : Those are the values I want to bring to the presidency and to the White House beginning in January of 1989.
Jim Lehrer : Governor
column2: a follow-up question.

column1: Jim Lehrer : You have two minutes to answer it.
Jim Lehrer : Are you suggesting
column2: sir
column3: that President Reagan is one of the causes of the drug problem in this country?

column1: Michael Dukakis : I'm saying that those of us who are elected to positions of political leadership
column2: Jim
column3: have a special responsibility
column4: not only to come up with programs
column5: and I have outlined in detail the very important
column6: very strong program of enforcement as well as drug education prevention.

column1: Michael Dukakis : And Mr. Bush is right - the two go hand in hand.
Michael Dukakis : But if our government itself is doing business with people who we know are engaged in drug profiteering and drug trafficking
column2: if we don't understand that that sends out a very
column3: very bad message to our young people
column4: it's a little difficult for me to understand just how we can reach out to that youngster that I talked about and to young people like her all over the country
column5: and say to them we want to help you.

column1: Michael Dukakis : Now
column2: I've outlined in great detail a program for being tough on enforcement at home and abroad
column3: doubling the number of drug enforcement agents
column4: having a hemispheric summit soon after the 20th of January when we bring our democratic neighbors and allies together here in this hemisphere and go to work together.

column1: Michael Dukakis : But we also have to take demand seriously.
Michael Dukakis : You know
column2: we have five percent of the world's population in this country.

column1: Michael Dukakis : We're consuming 50 percent of the world's cocaine.
Michael Dukakis : Doing better in the neighborhoods.
Michael Dukakis : But I think we're all in this together
column2: and my plea to the American people is values in the schools.

column3: second and third grade

column1: Michael Dukakis : If he or representatives of the administration are either with or involving people like Noriega in our foreign policy
column2: or don't pursue that connection in a way that makes it possible for us to cut it off and to be an example to our kids all over the country.

column1: Jim Lehrer : A minute to rebut
column2: Mr. Vice President.

column1: George Bush : Well
column2: the other day my opponent was given a briefing by the CIA.

column1: George Bush : I asked for and received the same briefing.
George Bush : I am very careful in public life about dealing with classified information.
George Bush : And what I'm about to say is unclassified.
George Bush : Seven administrations were dealing with Mr. Noriega.
George Bush : It was the Reagan-Bush administration that brought this man to justice.
George Bush : And as the governor of Massachusetts knows
column2: there was no evidence that governor - that Mr. Noriega was involved in drugs
column3: no hard evidence until we indicted him.

column1: George Bush : And so I think it's about time we get this Noriega matter in perspective.
George Bush : Panama is a friendly country.
George Bush : I went down there and talked to the president of Panama about cleaning up their money laundering
column2: and Mr. Noriega was there
column3: but there was no evidence at that time
column4: and when the evidence was there
column5: we indicted him.

column1: George Bush : And we want to bring him to justice.
George Bush : And so call off all those pickets out there that are trying to tear down seven different administrations.
Jim Lehrer : All right
column2: the next question will be asked by John Mashek.

column1: Jim Lehrer : It goes to Governor Dukakis
column2: and you'll have two minutes to answer.

column1: John Mashek : Governor Dukakis
column2: another troublesome issue for voters this year is the bulging federal deficit.

column1: John Mashek : In a Dukakis administration
column2: you say taxes will be raised only as a last resort.

column1: John Mashek : Would you identify for us then please three specific programs that you are willing to cut to bring that deficit down?
Michael Dukakis : Yes
column2: I've been very specific about those
column3: John.

column1: Michael Dukakis : And let me lay out for you my own strategy for bring that deficit down
column2: because as a chief executive that's balanced ten budgets in a row
column3: I've had to make those tough decisions and those tough choices.

column1: Michael Dukakis : First
column2: I've suggested that there are certain weapons systems which we don't need and we can't afford.

column1: Michael Dukakis : Mr. Bush has been critical of me for that
column2: but I think those are the kinds of tough choices you have to make.

column1: Michael Dukakis : I've also suggested that there are weapons systems that we should proceed on
column2: and I've outlined those in detail.

column1: Michael Dukakis : Secondly
column2: we've got to invest in economic growth in this country
column3: in every part of this country.

column1: Michael Dukakis : Building that kind of growth expands revenues and helps to bring down that deficit.
Michael Dukakis : Thirdly
column2: we have to bring interest rates down
column3: and we will as we come up with a good
column4: solid plan with the Congress for bringing that deficit down.

column1: Michael Dukakis : And
column2: finally
column3: we've got to go out there and collect billions and billions of dollars in taxes owed that aren't being paid to this country.

column1: Michael Dukakis : It's very unfair to the average taxpayer who pays his taxes and pays them on time to permit these monies to go uncollected.
Michael Dukakis : I've also suggested that on the domestic side there are areas where we can make some cuts.
Michael Dukakis : We ought to be able to come up with an agricultural policy in this country that gives our farm families a fair price and a decent future without spending $20-25 billion a year
column2: which is what we've been doing under this administration.

column1: Michael Dukakis : We can help people to live better lives
column2: and at the same time save money by helping hundreds of thousands of families on welfare to get off or welfare
column3: and to become productive citizens again.

column1: Michael Dukakis : The thing I don't understand about Mr. Bush's approach to this is how he could possibly be serious about bringing that deficit down given what he says he wants to do.
Michael Dukakis : He seems to want to spend a great deal of money on just about every weapon system; he says he's against new taxes
column2: although he's broken that pledge at least times in the last year that I know of; he wants to give the wealthiest taxpayers in this country a five year
column3: $40 billion tax break.

column1: Michael Dukakis : He also wants to spend a lot of money on additional programs.
Michael Dukakis : If he keeps this up
column2: he's going to be the Joe Isuzu of American politics.

column1: Michael Dukakis : (Laughter)
Michael Dukakis : But I hope you won't take my five seconds away from me.
Michael Dukakis : I will say this -
Jim Lehrer : Your two minutes is up
column2: Governor.

column1: Michael Dukakis : If he's serious about what he's saying
column2: then the only place he can go to balance that budget is to raid the Social Security Trust Fund
column3: and he tried that in 1985
column4: and I think he's going to try it again.

column1: Jim Lehrer : You have a minute to rebut.
George Bush : Is this the time to unleash our one-liners?
George Bush : That answer was about as clear as Boston harbor.
George Bush : (Laughter)
George Bush : Let me help the governor.
George Bush : There are so many things there
column2: I don't quite know where to begin.

column1: George Bush : When you cut capital gains
column2: you put people to work.

column1: George Bush : John Kennedy proposed cutting capital gains.
George Bush : Paul Tsongas
column2: a liberal senator from Massachusetts said the dumbest thing I did was to oppose the capital gains cut.

column1: George Bush : It's not going to cost the government money.
George Bush : It's going to increase revenues to the federal government
column2: and it's going to create jobs.

column1: George Bush : So that's one of the things that I think makes a big difference between us.
George Bush : Massachusetts doesn't have an enormous defense budget
column2: but nevertheless
column3: the governor raised taxes five different times.

column1: George Bush : That happens to be a fact.
George Bush : And so let's kind of stay on the issue
column2: and I have made a specific proposal for what I call a flexible freeze.

column1: George Bush : And it permits - economists on the East Coast and West think it's good - it permits the president to sort out the priorities
column2: and we continue to grow because I will not raise taxes.

column1: Jim Lehrer : Your time is up
column2: too.

column1: Jim Lehrer : A follow-up
column2: John.

column1: John Mashek : Mr. Vice President
column2: you have vowed not to raise taxes of any kind during your administration and at the same time you've proposed this capital gains cut
column3: you've proposed more incentive breaks for the oil industry.

column1: John Mashek : You've suggested new spending programs and even some Republicans say the flexible freeze you just spoke about will hardly make a dent in the deficit.
John Mashek : Is the deficit no longer really a concern of yours
column2: the Republican Party or the taxpayers?

column1: George Bush : I think it's the Republican Party and my concern to bring it down.
George Bush : And presidential leadership that I want to provide in this area will bring it down
column2: but we've got to get the Democrats - Congress under control.

column1: George Bush : They do all the spending
column2: they appropriate every dime and tell us how to spend every dime.

column1: George Bush : I'd like to ask the Governor to join in getting for the president what 43 governors have
column2: the line-item veto.

column1: George Bush : He has to operate in Massachusetts under a balanced budget proviso.
George Bush : I would like a balanced budget amendment.
George Bush : But the dynamics of the economy - we cut the taxes and revenues are up by 25 percent in three years.
George Bush : So the problem is - it's not that the working is being taxed too little or the person working out - the woman working in some factory being taxed too little.
George Bush : It is that we are continuing to spend too much.
George Bush : So
column2: my formula says grow at the rate of inflation.

column1: George Bush : Permit the president to set the priorities on where we do the spending.
George Bush : And remember the Federal deficit has come down $70 billion in one year
George Bush : And if we - and the - actually this year Congress is doing a little better in controlling the growth of spending.
George Bush : Spending was only up something like 4 percent.
George Bush : So
column2: it isn't that we're taking too little - from taxpayer - we're spending too much still.

column1: George Bush : And the formula I've given you works
column2: we've put it through a good economic model
column3: we've got good economists on the West Coast
column4: Michael Boskin and Marty Feldstein up there who's a very respected economist in the - Massachusetts.

column1: George Bush : And they agree
column2: that if we can do what I've said
column3: we can get it down without going and socking the American taxpayer once again.

column1: George Bush : Capital gains
column2: one more point on that
column3: please let's learn from history.

column1: George Bush : A capital gains differential will increase jobs
column2: increase risk taking
column3: increase revenues to the Federal Government.

column2: you have a minute to rebut.

column1: Michael Dukakis : Well
column2: I hope all of those Americans out there who are watching us
column3: listening to us and trying to make up their mind about which one of us ought to be president of the United States listen to the Vice President very carefully.

column1: Michael Dukakis : What he's proposing after over a trillion in new debt which has been added in the Federal debt in the course of the past eight years
column2: an IOU our children and grandchildren will be paying for years
column3: is a tax cut for the wealthiest one percent of the people in this country
column4: an average of about $30
column5: 000 that we're going to give to people making $200

column1: Michael Dukakis : Why that's more than the average teacher makes.
Michael Dukakis : We've had enough of that
column2: ladies and gentlemen.

column1: Michael Dukakis : We've run up more debt in the last eight years than under all the presidents from George Washington to Jimmy Carter combined.
Michael Dukakis : It's time for a chief executive who can make tough choices
column2: can work with the Congress
column3: can get that deficit down and begin to build a strong fiscal foundation under this country.

column1: Jim Lehrer : All right
column2: the next question will be asked by Anne Groer and it will go the Vice President.

column1: Jim Lehrer : You have two minutes to answer
column2: sir.

column1: Ann Groer : Mr. Vice President
column2: you've said you want a kinder
column3: gentler presidency
column4: one that helps the less fortunate.

column1: Ann Groer : Today
column2: 37 million Americans including many working families with aging parents and young children cannot afford any health insurance
column3: but earn too much to qualify for Medicaid.

column1: Ann Groer : What will you do to provide protection for them and how will you pay for it?
George Bush : One thing I will not do is sock every business in the country and
column2: thus
column3: throw some people out of work.

column1: George Bush : I want to keep this economic recovery going.
George Bush : More Americans at work today than any time in history
column2: a greater percentage of the work force.

column1: George Bush : What I will do is permit people to buy into Medicaid.
George Bush : I believe that's the answer.
George Bush : I am proud to have been part of an administration that past the first catastrophic health bill.
George Bush : And in that there are some Medicaid provisions that will be very helpful to the very kind of people we're talking about here.
George Bush : But we've got to keep going forward without killing off the engine and throwing people out of work.
George Bush : So
column2: the answer lies
column3: it seems to me
column4: in full enforcement of the catastrophic program.

column1: George Bush : "It lies to me in flexibility in Medicaid so people at the lowest end can buy in there and get their needs covered and then it also - I do not want to see us mandate across the board that every company has to do this
column2: because I really think that marginal operators are going to go say
column3: ""We can't make it."""

column1: George Bush : And I think then you're going to see that people are put out of work.
George Bush : All these programs - and this cost on his - is - was - I saw an estimate
column2: I'd love to know what he thinks
column3: $35 - $40 billion - and it seems to me that somebody pays that.

column1: George Bush : There isn't any such thing as something free out there.
George Bush : It either gets passed along as increased prices or it gets passed along by people being put out of work so the business can continue to compete.
George Bush : So
column2: I think we ought to do it in the Medicaid system.

column1: George Bush : I think we ought to do it by full enforcement of the catastrophic health insurance.
George Bush : I think we ought to do it by everybody doing what they can do out of conscience.
George Bush : It's a terrible problems in terms of flexibility on private insurance.
George Bush : But I just don't want to mandate it and risk putting this - setting the recovery back.
Jim Lehrer : A rebuttal
column2: Governor?

column1: Michael Dukakis : But
column2: George
column3: that's no answer.

column1: George Bush : You don't like the answer
column2: but it's an answer.

column1: Michael Dukakis : Well
column2: no
column3: it's no answer to those 37 million people
column4: most of them members of working families who don't have a dime of health insurance and don't know how to pay the bills if their kids get sick at night.

column1: Michael Dukakis : I was in Houston on Tuesday meeting with a group of good citizens
column2: working citizens.

column1: Michael Dukakis : All of them with little or no health insurance.
Michael Dukakis : One of them was a father who had been laid off a few months ago and lost his health insurance.
Michael Dukakis : Has an 11 year old son and can't let that son compete in sports and Little League
column2: because he's afraid he's going to get hurt and he won't be able to provide health insurance to pay those bills.

column1: Michael Dukakis : My state just became the only state in the nation to provide for universal health care and we did it with the support of the business community and labor and the health care community and with virtually everybody in the state.
Michael Dukakis : The fact of the matter is that employers who today are insuring their employees are paying the freight
column2: because they're paying for those who aren't.

column1: Michael Dukakis : And I think it's time that when you got a job in this country it came with health insurance.
Michael Dukakis : That's the way we're going to provide basic health security for all of the citizens of this country of ours.
Jim Lehrer : Follow-up
column2: Anne?

column1: Ann Groer : Yes.
Ann Groer : Since your Massachusetts health plan has been attacked by the Vice President and you have defended it in this way
column2: I would like to move on to perhaps one of the most costly medical catastrophes facing Americans today and that is AIDS.

column1: Ann Groer : In - at the end of September
column2: the thousands of AIDS patients will lose their access to AZT
column3: which is the only Federally approved drug for treatment of the disease.

column1: Ann Groer : Now
column2: I'd like to now
column3: sir
column4: if - what your position is on extending that and what it is you think the government ought to be doing about making AZT and other drugs available to people who are suffering from this disease.

column1: Michael Dukakis : Well
column2: Anne
column3: let me just say before I answer your question that I didn't know that the Vice President attacked our program in Massachusetts.

column1: Michael Dukakis : I hope he hasn't.
Michael Dukakis : Because has won the support of a great many people all over the state and I think it's a model for what I hope we can do across the country.
Michael Dukakis : But when I proposed my plan this past Tuesday
column2: he or one of his spokesmen called it socialized medicine.

column1: Michael Dukakis : The last time the Vice President used that phrase
column2: I suspect he remembers it
column3: don't you?

column1: Michael Dukakis : It was in 1964 and that's what he called Medicare.
Michael Dukakis : Well
column2: he was wrong then and he's wrong now.

column1: Michael Dukakis : (Applause)
Jim Lehrer : If I may interrupt at this point and caution the audience as I did before we went on the air
column2: please hold it down.

column1: Jim Lehrer : You're only taking time away from your candidate when you do that.
Jim Lehrer : Governor
column2: continue
column3: please.

column1: Michael Dukakis : Let me say this about AIDS.
Michael Dukakis : It's the single most important public health crisis
column2: single most important public health emergency we've had in our lifetimes and I think there are a number of things we have to do including supporting legislation which is now moving through the Congress
column3: which will commit this nation to the resources to find a cure which will provide broad education and prevention
column4: which will provide sensitive and caring treatment for the victims of AIDS.

column1: Michael Dukakis : I think we have to demonstrate some flexibility and I think the FDA is attempting to do so now in trying to make it possible for new and experimental drugs to be available to people who are at risk at AIDS and I would hope that we could bring that kind of a policy to bear beginning in January.
Michael Dukakis : And I would encourage the current administration to proceed with that kind of flexibility where it's appropriate and where it's done carefully and responsibly.
Michael Dukakis : But we have not had the kind of leadership we should have had.
Michael Dukakis : In this particular area
column2: I think the Vice President and I are in general agreement on what we have to do.

column1: Michael Dukakis : The special Federal commission made good solid recommendations.
Michael Dukakis : I think we're both supportive of them and I would strongly lead in that area as I have in my state as Governor.
Jim Lehrer : Mr. Vice President
column2: a minute of rebuttal.

column1: George Bush : Well
column2: we're on the right track.

column1: George Bush : The NIH is doing a good job in research.
George Bush : The Surgeon General is doing a good job in encouraging the proper kind of education.
George Bush : I notice that the Governor did not mention any testing.
George Bush : But we got to have a knowledge base.
George Bush : Testing should be confidential
column2: but we have to have a knowledge.

column1: George Bush : We can't simply stick our heads in the sands in terms of testing.
George Bush : I'm Chairman of the President's Task Force on Regulatory Relief and we are working with the FDA and they have sped up bringing drugs to market that can help.
George Bush : And you got to be careful here
column2: because there's a safety factor
column3: but I think these things - and then also I am one who believes we've got to go the extra mile in clean - being sure that that blood supply is pure.

column1: George Bush : We cannot have a lack of confidence in the blood supply when it comes to operations and surgery and things of this nature.
George Bush : So
column2: research
column3: speeding the drugs to market
column4: testing
column5: blood supply are very important elements of this.
